name: M-100ACE
ports: Parallel, Serial RS-232, Analogue-Digital converter, FD unit, S-100 bus
description:
The Sord M-100ACE was the professional version of the M-170, offering as standard a floppy disc controller card, a single or dual 5" 143 KB floppy disc unit and a colour graphic video card. 

Several I/O interfaces were also added and business oriented developpement tools could be used: FORTRAN and BASIC compilers and COBOL language.

Four successive version were sold - M100-I to M100-IV - offering various hardware and design improvements.
The model pictured here is a M100-III.

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> RIGHT SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>One can separate the FD unit from the main unit. The system is turned on/off with a key.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> TOP VIEW</strong></font><br><blockquote>The monochrome monitor also came from Sord.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FD UNIT</strong></font><br><blockquote>The FD unit featured two single side, single density, 143 KB formatted TEAC drives.<br><br> Notice the swith on each drive front panel, allowing the diskette to be locked inside the drive.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SORD LOGOS</strong></font><br><blockquote>Depending of the system version, the Sord logo may differ.<br><br> Notice the switch-on lock.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR CONNECTORS</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Power cord, ground plug and fuse<br> <b>(2)</b> FD drives DB37 connector<br> <b>(3)</b> Drives power supply connectors<br> <b>(4)</b> Three AC power plugs for external devices <br> <b>(5)</b> Monochrome video jack<br> <b>(6)</b> Analog/digital converter DB15 connector<br> <b>(7)</b> Serial RS-232 DB25 connector<br> <b>(8)</b> Parallel printer connector  </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The power supply unit has a stange design. It is made of:<br> <b>(1)</b> a massive power transformer with three relays<br> <b>(2)</b> Two identical switching power units<br> <b>(3)</b> a third 5V regulated circuit.<br> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SYSTEM BOARDS</strong></font><br><blockquote>The main CPU board covers the FD controller card and the video card.<br><br> <b>(1)</b> Keyboard cable<br> <b>(2)</b> 32 KB main RAM chips (16 x 4116 chips)<br> <b>(3)</b> Z80 processor, here a Zilog version<br> <b>(4)</b> BIOS ROM chips. Two additional ROM chips could be added.<br> <b>(5)</b> I/O bus connector<br> <b>(6)</b> Intel 8251 I/O chip<br> <b>(7)</b> Video card<br> <b>(8)</b> Floppy disc drives controller card.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DAUGHTER CARDS</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> A flat cable links the two daughter cards to the CPU board using these connectors<br> <b>(2)</b> Disc drives connector<br> <b>(3)</b> Composite video jack<br></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> CPU BOARD CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>Microprocessor, RAM and BIOS ROM chips.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> TEAC FLOPPY DRIVES</strong></font><br><blockquote>Single side, single density TEAC floppy drives.<br> Except screws, logic board and motors, the frame and all of the parts of these drives are made of plastic!</blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>Graphics examples of the optional graphic card.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Tim Mackay</b> </p></blockquote>
